{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3718892,"name":"James ","username":"TullE564","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tulle564/{size}/226301_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T02:41:15.608Z","cooked":"

Hello CD!

This off-season, I have been trying to get familiar with CAD, and to do so I have decided to design a tennis ball shooting robot in Onshape. I have no intention of building this, just using it to get familiar with the program. I have completed the chassis, bumpers, and electronics already, and as I began to think about manipulators, I realized I had no idea how to design the optimal funnel. I can make a funnel in any shape, but I have no idea what to do to minimize blockages or clogs. I looked to Steamworks for inspiration, but my questions still were’nt answered. I attached some designs I sketched for the sake of this post, with the first being much more realistic in my opinion (Based roughly off of teams such as Cheesy Poofs in 2017). All this being said, what do you guys take into account while designing funnels, and what could I improve? Thanks!

Screenshot 2025-08-19 10.31.09 PM484×460 56.4 KB

Don’t think the second uploaded, here it is. (I don’t love the design, I was just toying with some features)

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-08-20T02:43:40.086Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":455,"readers_count":454,"score":91.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505466,"topic_slug":"optimal-funnel-design","display_username":"James ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60429,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Driver"},"post_url":"/t/optimal-funnel-design/505466/2","custom_user_title":"Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3718913,"name":"wyatt","username":"stormsj28","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a3d4f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T02:56:35.504Z","cooked":"

I’ve seen mechanisms with “agitators” or something to keep the balls moving, usually like a corkscrew just to stop blocks, as for passive funnels having grooves or something similar may help to keep the balls where you want them.

Hope this helps a little bit:)

I had thought about agitators, and am actually surprised I don’t often see teams with them. I suppose if you can get by without one you save a motor. I’ll look into the grooves a bit more, that’s an interesting idea.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-08-20T03:24:38.413Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":400,"readers_count":399,"score":85.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505466,"topic_slug":"optimal-funnel-design","display_username":"James ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":76247,"username":"stormsj28","name":"wyatt","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a3d4f5/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60429,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Driver"},"post_url":"/t/optimal-funnel-design/505466/5","custom_user_title":"Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3718938,"name":"wyatt","username":"stormsj28","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a3d4f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T03:30:15.713Z","cooked":"

I think we don’t see funnels or hoppers as much because lots of team usually design magazines or like a “staged” hopper (infinite recharge has a lot of these style things) but just out of curiosity why are you going with a funnel or hopper? Is it just so you can hold more or is it more simplistic

Edit:
Also is your design going to have a ground collect? Just wondering what it looks like:)

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-08-20T03:32:03.158Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":394,"readers_count":393,"score":143.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505466,"topic_slug":"optimal-funnel-design","display_username":"wyatt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3218 CAD"},"post_url":"/t/optimal-funnel-design/505466/6","custom_user_title":"3218 CAD","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3718941,"name":"Andrew Torrance","username":"Torrance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/torrance/{size}/152754_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T03:35:01.617Z","cooked":"

Ultimately, you’ll have to prototype it.

That said, some general rules of thumb:

Passive funnels are simple to make, but often jam with lots of game objects (2017, form little “bridges” across width of funnel) or objects that cannot slide past each other (2020 balls). If all you can do is a passive funnel, make it as steep as possible and with slippery sides (polycarb or delrin, or cover it in PTFE tape). Preferably do both (254-2025).

Better than passive would be something active. Powered rollers that actually pull the game objects through the funnel, and at the same time agitating and preventing jams (118-2017, 973-2017. If powered on both left and right or top bottom, sometimes helps to have a slight speed difference between the sides so asymmetry prevents jams. Can also shape the funnels asymmetrically which can help.

In between totally passive and powered funnel is something with an added agitator. A spinny wheel on one side geared off your main intake or feeder/shooter. Or maybe the deploy/retract of the entire intake agitates the hopper. (ex 148-2017).

All this said, classic design wisdom applies. Design what is within the resources (time, money, knowledge) of your team and best serves your goals for the season (make elims, win an event, win Einstein). Sometimes the simpler but done-sooner design you can tweak is better than spending weeks designing and building something theoretically 5% faster, but a more complicated design.

Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T03:37:28.653Z","cooked":"
stormsj28:

I think we don’t see funnels or hoppers as much because lots of team usually design magazines or like a “staged” hopper (infinite recharge has a lot of these style things) but just out of curiosity why are you going with a funnel or hopper? Is it just so you can hold more or is it more simplistic

A lot of that also depends on the final exit point of the game piece. In 2017, the fuel shooter couldn’t be much higher than the fuel itself (and done right, there was way more fuel than you could ever stage up in a nice neat line). 2020/21, robots that shrugged off going under the control panel had plenty of room to queue up at least most if not all of the power cells.

To that end, is OP under the constraint of having a central exit? An exit skewed to a side might make a powered agitator easier to implement.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-08-20T03:37:28.653Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":330,"readers_count":329,"score":131.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505466,"topic_slug":"optimal-funnel-design","display_username":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":3095,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"says you should come to SCRIW in October"},"post_url":"/t/optimal-funnel-design/505466/8","custom_user_title":"says you should come to SCRIW in October","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3718993,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T05:11:38.021Z","cooked":"

Most of the reason you don’t normally see teams with agitators is that there’s a limited number of game pieces a robot can hold, so most of the time a hopper isn’t built. Instead, the entire game piece storage is a conveyor that’s focused on getting the game piece lined up to go into the shooter.

You want to look at 2006, 2009, and 2017. Maybe a dose of 2012 and 2020/2021, which had higher limits but still needed a little bit of organization.

2017 will be closer to the “tennis ball” setup, to be fair–but a look at how things were handled earlier may give a couple of clues.

One other key factor: How the game pieces interact with each other when in a pile would be quite insightful. I wouldn’t do it for just a design exercise, but if there were a game where I needed to store a lot of tennis balls on my robot, the very first thing I would do would be to go get a bunch of tennis balls and pile them up and see what they did as far as settling down, forming bridges, does that change with using different materials for the containment of the pile, etc. If they’re dropping through with minimal issue, no agitator needed. If they’re needing agitation to move, then how much agitation becomes a key factor in designing the chute or agitation methods.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-08-20T05:11:38.021Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":277,"readers_count":276,"score":120.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505466,"topic_slug":"optimal-funnel-design","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60429,"username":"TullE564","name":"James ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tulle564/{size}/226301_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/optimal-funnel-design/505466/9","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3719075,"name":"James ","username":"TullE564","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tulle564/{size}/226301_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T12:53:56.454Z","cooked":"

I completely agree with this, what is hard about me doing this without a true reason is that I can’t test and prototype. Had I been able to test funnel designs with numerous balls in real life, I would.

Currently not many constraints as the robot is being designed from scratch. I was looking to hold a lot of balls, which is why I gravitated towards a funnel rather than a powered alignment / storage mechanism.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-08-20T12:56:04.225Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":201,"readers_count":200,"score":45.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505466,"topic_slug":"optimal-funnel-design","display_username":"James ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":3095,"username":"Billfred","name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60429,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Driver"},"post_url":"/t/optimal-funnel-design/505466/11","custom_user_title":"Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3719082,"name":"James ","username":"TullE564","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tulle564/{size}/226301_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T13:01:36.998Z","cooked":"

Holding a lot of balls was the goal for me, which is why I planned on a funnel. I had thought of other, more organized methods of storage (1717’s 2009 Helix came to mind as I am currently reading Neal Bascomb’s ‘The New Cool’). I’m planning on designing an OTB ground intake to work in tangent with this storage, mostly to give me another moving part to design.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-08-20T13:01:36.998Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":192,"readers_count":191,"score":58.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505466,"topic_slug":"optimal-funnel-design","display_username":"James ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":76247,"username":"stormsj28","name":"wyatt","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a3d4f5/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60429,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Driver"},"post_url":"/t/optimal-funnel-design/505466/12","custom_user_title":"Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3719150,"name":"Tom","username":"Zook","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zook/{size}/252720_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T14:15:19.668Z","cooked":"
TullE564:

I can’t test and prototype

I’ll just say it, you’ll never have an “optimal” design if you can’t test and prototype.

Since you’re looking to improve CAD skills, I’d recommend a different strategy. Try to copy designs of robots that proved close to “optimal” on the field (say champs winners), then look at their tech binders or released CAD (if they exist).

Tennis balls (fuzzy, rubber) react different under pressure than the fuel cells (slippery, plastic). So optimizing a design without any hands-on data to feedback into the process is never going to really be optimized.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-08-20T14:15:19.668Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":180,"readers_count":179,"score":106.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505466,"topic_slug":"optimal-funnel-design","display_username":"Tom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4276 nice mentor"},"post_url":"/t/optimal-funnel-design/505466/13","custom_user_title":"4276 nice mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3719235,"name":"","username":"Kevin_Leonard","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kevin_leonard/{size}/237299_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-20T14:48:55.211Z","cooked":"
Zook:

I’ll just say it, you’ll never have an “optimal” design if you can’t test and prototype.

Teams in general only have so many things they can prototype before they need to commit to a design during build season.

3467 is historically a pretty low-prototyping team, preferring to grab things we “know” will work based on historical robot design and prototypes other teams post online to confirm our assumptions.

@TullE564 picking some design you “know” will work might be a better starting point, such as putting all the balls in a line (like many 2012/2022 robots) or even an S shape (like a couple 2020 robots https://youtu.be/MrewC-tz3x8?si=gRPPaALVO2FL8Jmj&t=54 ) and control the balls on both sides.

2012 robot example

image720×746 51.9 KB

Another option of a “known” design are the V-shaped belt hoppers from 2020 that worked pretty well for those balls. No guarantee that it would work with tennis balls, but I’d bet money you could design one and then tweak it once it’s built to work pretty well.

And example from 319’s 2020 public CAD:

cad.onshape.com

Onshape

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

One more design that hasn’t been mentioned yet is the spindexer, which has a large thingy in the middle that stores shots in multiple chambers and spins them around to index. A decent number of teams used them in 2017 and 2020 and they are extremely good at indexing a lot of things quickly and with perfectly consistent spacing, but require careful design of the exit geometry to avoid jams.
